title: Tuesday, 11th October, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:02 am
BE

Hi, welcome, hello, hey. This is Markets Live, FT Alphaville's daily thing.

BE

The main benefit of which is that I get to pick the picture.

BE

11:03 am
BE

It's Ada Lovelace Day.

BE

And that's from Sydney Padua's The Thrilling Adventures of Lovelace and Babbage.

BE

Which I can't recommend highly enough. Buy three copies each. Possibly five.

11:04 am
BE

https://www.amazon...uter/dp/0141981512

undefined

BE

Though is showing no particular urgency.

BE

Ahead 6.5 points at 7104 at pixel.

11:07 am

The record closing high's 7103.98 on 27/4//15, in case you care.

BE

Intraday is 7,122.74.

BE

And yes, of course it's a sterling effect.

11:08 am

BE

"Because that's what we've been trying to achieve for the past three years and now we have a chance of getting it."

It's good news that the nation's worth a fifth less than it was. Fair enough.

undefined
11:14 am
BE

Anyway, where do we begin?

BE

Before moving to stuff that's trading, best mention something that isn't.

BE

October 11 2016, London – Pure Gym, the UK’s leading gym operator, today announces that it will not proceed with an Initial Public Offering. Having announced its Intention to Float on 14 September 2016, the Board has decided that pursuing a listing in this period of market volatility is not in the long-term interests of the Company and its stakeholders.

11:15 am
BE

Humphrey Cobbold, Chief Executive Officer of Pure Gym, said; “Given the challenging IPO market conditions, the Board has decided not to proceed with a listing despite the strong interest shown by potential investors. Pure Gym’s excellent growth track record and market leading position give us a solid platform for further expansion in the attractive gym market. This year alone we have opened 35 new Pure Gyms1 and had over 150,000 new members join. Current trading is strong giving us further confidence that we can capitalise on the significant market opportunity and encourage even more people to become fitter and healthier.”

BE

Yep, okay.

BE

You can see by looking at the FTSE all-share how challenging it's been since Sept 14.

11:16 am
BE

BE

And by looking at the list of other IPOs in western Europe to have pulled since then. (None.)

BE

I make it £4.5bn IPOs announced in that period in Western Europe, £3.5bn of which were UK.

11:17 am
BE

Want the full list?

BE

Premier Asset Management, Mila Resources, Internationella Engelska Skola, Innova Italy and Crunchfish were all priced.

BE

The first three are priced and already trading.

11:17 am
BE

Misys, Biffa, Covatec, Officefirst, TI Fluid Systems, Shop Apotheke, Playa Hotels have all announced.

BE

So maybe Pure Gyms is the canary here. Perhaps the IPO market's stalling.

BE

Or perhaps people just don't want to buy buy a business in a sector absolutely littered with bankruptcies.

11:19 am
BE

Dunno. Whichever.

BE

(@Stateless: that was DB's GBP trade weight spot index I think)

undefined
11:21 am
BE

And so, to corporate news.

N Brown Group PLC (BWNG:LSE): Last: 204.54, up 28.64 (+16.28%), High: 210.00, Low: 190.00, Volume: 1.47m
BE

!!!!!!!

11:22 am
BE

H1's slightly better than expected.

BE

Current trading is fine, in the sense that it's not a warning.

BE

Why is this worth 17% on the price? I don't know.

11:24 am
BE

Jefferies does though, so here's them.

BE

1H17 is on the better side of consensus, 2H17 trading to date is on track & the
dividend (yielding 8%) is held flat. Given weakness into this release, there's
good reason here to see a strong share price bounce.

BE

They're house broker. But you could've guessed that.

11:24 am
BE

1H17 PBT at £31.6m is a touch above the £30.5m consensus & in line with JEFe at
£31.5m. 2Q product revenue growth reached +2.7% yoy from -1.6% 1Q, taking 1H product
sales to £300.9m vs JEFe at £294m. The 55.9% product gross margin was as we expected,
so costs slightly above our model delivered group PBT to our forecast. The cash exceptional
for financial services customer redress is set at £9m, just above the £5-8m range steered last
month. Autumn Winter has started in line with plans (a "more assertive" stance on pricing
taken) & 6 weeks into 2H, management is comfortable with FY17 market expectations. We
leave our forecasts unchanged.

BE

Power Brands continue to lead the performance: 1H17 product sales up 11% at JD
Williams brand, up 6% at Simply Be & up 3% at Jacamo are built on active customer numbers
up 15% yoy across these core brands. Consistent with past trends, Secondary Brand revenue
was flat at 0.4% yoy & Traditional down 4.2%, though actions to improve this performance
are "starting to have a positive impact". Fifty Plus also continues to weigh (active customers
sharply down) as marketing is reduced in preparation to migrate the customer file into JDW
over the coming two seasons.

BE

New Fit 4 the Future (F4tF) timetable - the first UK brand will now transition to the
new platform in 1Q18 (qtr ending May 17) with Simply Be to follow in 3Q18. Though
the new timetable now does not anticipate completing the roll out across all brands until
Summer 2018, we think the Simply Be launch will represent the point of maximum risk &
key milestone to pass next year. Indeed the group expects most of the online functionality to
have been delivered at that point, allowing it to downscale the programme & related costs
to complete the final stages as "normal business activity". FY18 capex is now seen at £40m
(from £30-40m previously) to capture the stretched F4tF timetable. The scale & timing of
targeted benefits remain unchanged: £45m (before any reinvestment) to begin realising in
FY18 & fully delivered from FY20.

11:25 am
BE

Valuation/Risks
We have a 250p PE based price target. As for other retailers, there's the unknown of the post
Brexit economy & GBP weakness to navigate. Other risks include: UK retail trends, bad debt/
debtor book, sector valuation, FX, strategy & F4tF execution risks.

BE

And Citi.

BE

Consensus PBT likely to remain unchanged — On the back of this statement we do not expect FY17E consensus PBT to change significantly. We have a FY17E PBT forecast £79.3m (EPS 22.7p, -9.3% yoy), this assumes FY total sales of +1.9%. We assume FY gross margins -70bp with opex growth of +3%. This drives forecast EBIT growth of -8.9% yoy. Our FY17E PBT forecast of £79.3m (-10.2% yoy.

11:26 am
BE

Neutral rating, TP 180p

We value N Brown on c. 9. 5x EV/EBIT for Feb 2018E in line with its recent average, this equates to c9x PE and a 6% dividend yield in the same forecast year.

BE

And Exane, just off the conference call.

BE

On a reassuring call, N Brown management reiterated the progress being made across elements of the business. Proposition improvements absent of any associated disruption, alongside a statement which met expectations and left guidance unchanged, could be considered a turning point. Progress at power brands, website relaunches and planning system improvements all point to the hope of benefits from multiple years of disruption and investment. And whilst a cautious tone was applied to the outlook (particularly currency-driven gross margin headwinds) and credit metrics raise questions, they are unlikely to get significant attention today. Whilst near-terms fears have been abated, and the extent of cost control provides a greater level of support to consensus FY17 forecasts, in our opinion today does little to calm fears over the longer-term outlook.

11:28 am
BE

I feel I'm going to have to go through the credit numbers here .... Arrears rate of 9.8% and 120k new recruits are the headlines.

Victrex PLC (VCT:LSE): Last: 1,741, up 118.74 (+7.32%), High: 1,824, Low: 1,616, Volume: 443.28k
11:37 am
PM

http://www.investe...1610110700051617M/

BE

Not sure it is that heavily shorted, incidentally. Certainly not in Markit's top 20 as % of market cap.

BE

Anyway, Q4 revenue beats and guidance stays the same.

11:38 am
BE

Liberum incoming.

BE

Victrex closing year update, ahead of full earnings on 6 December, was reassuring with 4Q volume and revenues 10% and 5% ahead of consensus respectively. As predicted 4Q revenues and volumes were significantly higher than the previous quarters (26% and 23% up on 3Q) thanks to the pre-launch ramp of the key consumer electronics customer. As was the case at the 3Q stage Victrex is guiding to 'significantly lower' contract volumes in Consumer Electronics in 2017 (due to a lower share position post-launch we believe) but this has already been anticipated by most analysts and will be fully offset in our view by FX tailwinds of £18m. The 2017 estimated FX impact is in our estimates but not the estimated £18m tailwind in 2018. Importantly, the CE contract relates to low grade PEEK resin where technical barriers are low. We remain buyers with DCF fair value standing around £21 and believe the outlook for cons estimates is likely up not down underpinned by c£38m 2 year FX tailwinds. FCF and Divi yield including specials are attractive at greater than 5%.

BE

Bernstein also keen.

11:38 am
BE

Victrex is a quality company that now offers an attractive entry point. We forecast an inflection point in growth and conclude that returns have a significant leverage to volumes. ROIC will grow steadily after the recent capacity addition leaves plenty headroom. Currency moves will improve Victrex's competitive position due to its international sales and high UK cost base. We see plenty of catalysts for share price performance from earnings updates (crowding score 8, the lowest in the sector), rig counts, cash returns, progress on mega-project, and M&A.

BE

And Singer.

BE

Victrex’ year end update confirms a strong Q4 performance, driven by the anticipated surge in demand from its large consumer electronics programme. Full year volume and revenue are both a touch ahead of our forecasts and consensus expectations. Invibio has delivered a steady year, in line with expectations, and the Magma oil & gas project has delivered its first meaningful revenues of over £1m. The outlook reiterates previous caution over the consumer electronics outlook but we believe this is now reflected in most analysts’ forecasts, including our own. There is no mention of currency, but this is clearly a strong tailwind for FY17 and, if current rates persist, into FY18. Overall, today’s statement should be well received. There was a lot to do in Q4 and Victrex has delivered it. In our view, the FY17 rating of 16x with a 6% yield (inc. 3% special) represents an attractive entry point for this high quality group.

11:39 am
BE

So ........ that.

11:41 am
PM

JPM

BE

Oh, go on then.

PM

Brexit fretting

11:42 am
PM

Article 50, which will be invoked by next Spring, covers the withdrawal agreement. This is the legal divorce rather than the new relationship. There is a two-year ticking clock in article 50, but, in our view, an extension of the negotiations would be agreed if needed. The real time constraint is not the ticking clock but rather the next UK election. The UK government wants EU exit completed by the next UK general election in mid-2020.

The reason why this timing is a problem is that it will take well beyond 2020 to negotiate and ratify a new free trade deal. This leaves the problem of what happens in the interregnum. There will need to be some kind of temporary patch to keep trade going. Otherwise, trade would collapse to being governed by WTO trading rules, which would be a major economic shock, especially for the services sector. In its open letter to the government on the Brexit negotiations, the CBI has argued that “the Government should therefore secure agreement of a transitional period, to ensure that businesses can continue to operate with no 'cliff edge' change to current circumstances until regulatory and legal changes can be implemented”.

The temporary arrangement could be time-limited membership of the EEA. But, in our view, the May administration is not building a political platform to argue for such action. Instead, rhetoric emphasizing the need to reassert control of the migration regime and regulatory issues is dominant. And once the negotiations with the EU begin, it is likely to be difficult to change tack toward a transitional period of EEA membership as part of the discussions. As negotiators begin to work through the issues subject to a time constraint, shifting to a different legal form of arrangement would entail costs in the form of further delays.

PM

As a result, it looks likely that there will have to be some kind of sector by sector transitional agreement to facilitate trade while discussions on a final settlement continue. Article 50 does not give an explicit competence to the EC to negotiate a temporary trading deal. Moreover, it does not appear likely that there would be an ability for the EC to agree such a set of temporary deals without them requiring ratification in all of the parliaments within the EU. During the Euro area crisis, the region demonstrated an ability to get such ratification done on an accelerated schedule. But with a broader set of countries involved, the risk that the ratification process becomes bogged down and hinders trade in at least some sectors is clear. The same ratification process will apply to any “final” trade deal.

So there are problems with the path ahead in terms of timing and legal process. The other problem is the content of the future free trade deal. The UK government is viewing the negotiations as transactional: that is, Europeans want to export stuff to the UK, the UK wants to export stuff to the EU, so what’s the problem. In contrast, the rest of the EU is viewing the negotiations as existential. They will define the future or even the very survival of the EU. An exit template which allowed the UK to exploit the perceived advantages of trade while not pooling as much sovereignty as others in the region could prove attractive to other EU members. Hence the very clear message from the rest of the EU is that the UK should bear some cost of Brexit. Most likely this will be in terms of trade in services, especially financial services.

PM

And Malcolm fretting specifically about his own indusry...

11:43 am
PM

There are at least four reasons why financial services looks particularly exposed to the Brexit process. First, its relatively high value added per employee suggests any shift in the location of activity will bring not just jobs but significant tax revenue. Second, the EU would prefer to oversee and regulate much of its own financial plumbing as possible, rather than delegating that to authorities in London. Third, the global multi-lateral mechanisms for facilitating free trade in goods are far more developed than for those in services, with the latter far more dependent on bespoke arrangements (like the EU). And fourth, activity relocating from London would likely provide the EU with some strong symbolism of what leaving the EU means in practice.

PM

Yup.

PM

And on the krona...

11:43 am
PM

How does the recent acceleration of sterling’s decline impact all this? Although the decline may suggest markets take a less optimistic view on the UK’s prospects than those who have argued for Brexit, it has little impact on the political discussion directly. Indeed, some will welcome the decline as helpful to a broader rebalancing of the economy. And the May administration appears minded to be more activist about achieving that rebalancing. Rather, the near-term channel of impact would come if the weakness of sterling was reflective of, or encouraged, a sharp decline across asset values more broadly. To date, there has been relatively little sign of that occurring.

On a more medium-term basis, we are rather skeptical of the UK economy’s ability to exploit a lower value of sterling (as explained by Allan Monks yesterday). Recently, the UK has tended to catch the downside of such depreciation, with import price increases pushing down on real incomes and consumer spending. But it has not tended to see much upside, with exporters failing to redeploy higher margins in investment and domestic companies not able to replace imports. Our forecast for slower UK growth next year partly reflects these forces. But although a sluggish growth environment will not help the May administration, the extent of growth weakness we are anticipating also does not look like it will be enough to generate a rethink on how Brexit is handled. There is a degree of political tolerance for transitional costs if “the Brexit people voted for” is being delivered.

PM

11:50 am
BE

Yep. I think those fingers need a few more flames, in this context.

BE

Here's Citi to give you the upshot.

BE

After market, ILMN announced prelim 3Q revs of $607M (+10% y/y) vs. guidance of $625-630M & consensus of $628M. EPS was not provided. Looking ahead, revs will likely now be flat to modestly up in 4Q, which has ~$70M coming out of our model. This marks the fourth miss in 6 quarters, as forecasting capabilities have clearly diminished. With confidence in the near term simply not there at this point, we are downgrading to Neutral and setting our 12-mth target price at $140 (38x our new ’17 EPS est). The lower multiple of 38x (from 43x) reflects a reduced growth outlook for 2016 and 2017, as well as a reduced level of confidence in forecasting and execution over the next 12 months. While the stock was down ~24% in after-hours trading, we would not be surprised to see shares touch $110-120 tomorrow.

11:50 am
BE

High-Throughput Order Visibility Remains an Issue
Mgmt’s call was notably short on details, but this qtr issues stem from weak HiSeq 2500/4000 demand in the US, as well as the drop-out of a multi-system HiSeq X order from one customer. In total, sequencing box sales are expected to be down 26% y/y in 3Q, while consumables were generally in-line with expectations – bolstered by a large order from an X customer. For 4Q, a HiSeq placement rebound is no longer assumed.

BE

Rough Cut on the Model
Our first pass at revisions puts revs up 8% this yr (down from 12%) & EPS at $3.20. For ‘17, we now project 12.5% rev growth & EPS of $3.70 (from $4.10).This assumes another down yr on instruments off a 17% decline in ’16, which feels conservative, but for now we’re comfortable taking the under.

BE

So What Now?
Obviously details on 11/1 are needed. We continue to believe in the long-term outlook for ILMN, as the overall NGS opportunity is huge and ILMN is a best-in-class asset. That said, something is currently not right. We do not believe it is competition (TMO seems status quo, Oxford’s high-throughput box is delayed, QGEN has yet to make its mark), and it could be as straight-forward as customers needing time to absorb capacity. With ILMN’s new CEO not hitting his stride as the long-time CFO prepares to depart, however, investors will likely need better answers to questions about market factors, and better overall execution in terms of projecting numbers that can be hit in order for a full ‘17 rebound story to materialize.

A reminder that Radius is mostly abaloparatide, for osteoporosis.

BE

It's inPhase III of a transdermal patch formulation of abaloparatide, which is gunning for Eli Lilly's Forteo (or Forsteo outside the US)

BE

Forteo being injection for people who can't for whatever reason tolerate normal bisphosphonates, which are what you use to add bone density.

11:58 am

Bisphosphonates are plentiful and cheap, whereas Forteo is very expensive, which is what makes it a $1bn+ drug
